statement.text: For most physical quantities, Planck units are NOT the smallest measurable values—they represent theoretical scales where quantum gravity becomes important. For many quantities (mass, energy, force, voltage, current), Planck values are ENORMOUS. Only for length and time are Planck values genuinely tiny (though still unmeasurable). This overview compares the smallest measurable or detectable values with corresponding Planck units to clarify this important distinction.
statement.key_insight: Planck units are natural scales from fundamental constants (ℏ, c, G), but 'natural' ≠ 'minimum'. Planck mass (~22 μg) is larger than bacteria. Planck energy (~2 GJ) equals 40 liters of gasoline. Only Planck length (~10⁻³⁵ m) and Planck time (~10⁻⁴⁴ s) are candidates for true fundamental minima.

summary_table.description: Comparison of Planck units vs smallest measurable values

quantities.ratio: Planck is 10¹⁷× SMALLER than best measurement
Planck is 10²³× SMALLER than best measurement

key_conclusions: Planck units mark where quantum gravity becomes important, NOT minimum measurable values
For mass, energy, force, voltage, current, fields: Planck values are ENORMOUS
For length and time: Planck values ARE genuinely tiny (possibly true minima)
For temperature: Planck temperature is a MAXIMUM, not minimum (absolute zero is minimum)
For charge: Elementary charge e is smaller than Planck charge by factor √137
Practical measurement limits come from noise (thermal, shot, quantum), not Planck physics

true_theoretical_minima.length: Planck length may be fundamental minimum (quantum spacetime)
true_theoretical_minima.time: Planck time may be fundamental minimum (quantum spacetime)
true_theoretical_minima.temperature: Absolute zero (0 K) is true minimum (unattainable)
true_theoretical_minima.charge: Elementary charge e is smallest free charge

no_fundamental_minimum.mass: No minimum—photons/gluons are massless; neutrinos have tiny but nonzero mass
no_fundamental_minimum.energy: No minimum—photon energy E = hν can be arbitrarily small (ν → 0)
no_fundamental_minimum.force: No minimum—just noise floors from thermal/quantum fluctuations
no_fundamental_minimum.current: No minimum—limited by e/τ for measurement time τ

related.relationship: Planck units are natural scales, not minima

sources.description: Synthesized from individual AKUs on minimum measurable quantities

learning_objectives: Understand that Planck units ≠ minimum measurable values for most quantities
Know which quantities have true minima (length, time, temperature, charge) vs noise-limited
Appreciate the orders of magnitude involved in these comparisons
Recognize that practical limits come from noise, not Planck physics
common_misconceptions: Planck mass is NOT the smallest mass—it's ~22 μg, quite large
Planck energy is NOT the smallest energy—it's ~2 GJ, enormous
Planck temperature is NOT minimum—it's MAXIMUM (~10³² K)
Planck charge is NOT minimum—it's 11.7× larger than e
